title: Underclock Your Computer Hardware: 2 Easy Ways

steps.title: Open the computer's BIOS/UEFI settings.
steps.content: Open the computer's BIOS/UEFI settings. Luigi Oppido notes the process usually involves pressing keys during the boot process, but those keys vary by manufacturer and model. Some manufacturers require pressing "Delete," "F2," or <alt>+ or other key combinations while the system goes through POST (Power On Self Test) or displays a logo on the screen. Alternatively, you can use the following steps to enter the BIOS/UEFI from within Windows: Open the Start menu and click the Power icon. Hold Shift as you click Restart . Wait for your computer to boot into Recovery Mode. Go to Troubleshoot > Advanced Options > UEFI Firmware Settings . Click Restart .

steps.title: Locate "Frequency/Voltage Control" settings.
steps.content: Locate "Frequency/Voltage Control" settings. BIOS screens generally consist of several pages of settings, each relating to certain parts of the PC's operation. Use the arrow keys to navigate to the screen with frequency and voltage control options. Note: Not all computer BIOS have "Frequency/Voltage Control" settings. In some cases, the manufacturer may lock the clock speed.

steps.title: Lower the "CPU Frequency."
steps.content: Lower the "CPU Frequency." You'll usually use the arrow keys, + and = keys, or other combinations to lower the value.

steps.title: Lower the CPU clock speed or ratio.
steps.content: Lower the CPU clock speed or ratio. Lower these values in a way similar to the way described above. Note that the performance decreases linearly to the clock speed.

steps.title: Lower the core voltage (vCore).
steps.content: Lower the core voltage (vCore). The CPU's specs will mostly behave linearly, so a 10% decrease in voltage will need about a 10% decrease in clock speed.

steps.title: Save and exit the BIOS.
steps.content: Save and exit the BIOS. When complete, save the settings before exiting. Otherwise, the old settings will remain in place. If you think you've made a mistake, press the "Esc" key to exit without saving.

steps.title: Download and install MSI Afterburner.
steps.content: Download and install MSI Afterburner. MSI Afterburner is a free Windows program used to underclock, undervolt , and overclock your graphics card (GPU). To install MSI Afterburner: Go to https://www.msi.com/Landing/afterburner/graphics-cards . Click the Final button at the bottom to download the ZIP file. Extract the ZIP file in your Downloads file. Double-click the setup file you extracted and follow the instructions to complete the installation.

steps.title: Open MSI Afterburner.
steps.content: Open MSI Afterburner. It has a green circular icon with an image that resembles a jet. Make sure your graphics card is detected. It should be displayed at the bottom center of the MSI Afterburner window.

steps.title: Run a benchmark test.
steps.content: Run a benchmark test. You can run a benchmark test using a benchmark test program like Heaven Benchmark to test your GPU. [1] X Research source Check the temperature of your GPU in MSI Afterburner while testing your GPU.

steps.title: Lower your clock speed.
steps.content: Lower your clock speed. Use the slider bar below "Core Clock (MHz)" to lower your clock speed. To avoid underclocking your GPU by too much, use smaller increments of no more than 50 MHz.

steps.title: Lower the memory clock speed.
steps.content: Lower the memory clock speed. Use the slider bar below "Memory Clock (MHz)" to lower the memory clock speed. Lower it the same amount you lowered the core clock speed.

steps.title: Apply the changes.
steps.content: Apply the changes. To do so, click the icon that resembles a checkmark at the bottom center of the MSI Afterburner window.

steps.title: Run another benchmark test.
steps.content: Run another benchmark test. Use a game with high-quality graphics or Heaven Benchmark to do another benchmark test of your GPU. Check to see if your GPU temperature is reduced. Also, check to see if there are any performance problems while the benchmark test is running. If your computer restarts or you experience performance issues while using GPU-intensive programs or running a benchmark test, raise the clock speed by about 50 MHz at a time and see if this fixes the problem.

steps.title: Save the setting to a profile.
steps.content: Save the setting to a profile. You can save your underclock settings to one of the number profiles. Click the profile you want to save your underclock setting to, and then click the icon that resembles a floppy disk at the bottom of the MSI Afterburner window.
